[[File:Ted Nasmith - Beren, Song of Parting.jpg|250px|thumb|''Beren: Song of Parting'' by [[Ted Nasmith]]]] The '''Song of Parting''' was [[Beren|Beren Erchamion]]'s song of farewell to [[Lúthien|Lúthien Tinúviel]]. It was sung by him in the ''[[Lay of Leithian]]'' as he left her for [[Angband]], even as he looked across [[Anfauglith]].{{LB|C11}}, vv. 3298-3333 It is arguably among the best parts of the Lay, as a part of it was included in the ''[[Quenta Silmarillion]]''.{{S|Beren}} ==In ''The Silmarillion''== A part of the song is given in the Chapter 19 "[[Of Beren and Lúthien]]" of ''[[The Silmarillion]]''. This is also included in the third edition of the [[The Road Goes Ever On (book)|''The Road Goes Ever On'']], as the 9th song, with music by [[Donald Swann]]. [[File:Christopher Tolkien - Song of Parting.wav|thumb|left|[[Christopher Tolkien]] reads The Song of Parting]]




Farewell sweet earth and northern sky, for ever blest, since here did lie and here with lissom limbs did run beneath the [[Moon]], beneath the [[Sun]], Lúthien Tinúviel more fair than mortal tongue can tell. Though all to ruin fell the world and were dissolved and backward hurled unmade into the old abyss, yet were its making good, for this— the dawn, the dusk, the earth, the sea— that Lúthien on a time should be! ==In ''The Lays of Beleriand''== The full song is given in ''[[The Lays of Beleriand]]'', part III "[[The Lay of Leithian]]: [[Lay of Leithian Canto XI|Canto XI]]". Farewell now here, ye leaves of trees, your music in the morning breeze! Farewell now blade and bloom and grass that see the changing seasons pass; ye waters murmuring over stone, and meres that silent stand alone! Farewell now mountain, vale, and plain! Farewell now wind and frost and rain, and mist and cloud, and heaven's air; ye star and moon so blinding-fair that still shall look down from the sky on the wide earth, though Beren die— though Beren die not, and yet deep, deep, whence comes of those that weep no dreadful echo, lie and choke in everlasting dark and smoke. Farewell sweet earth and northern sky, for ever blest, since here did lie, and here with lissom limbs did run, beneath the moon, beneath the sun, Lúthien Tinúviel more fair than mortal tongue can tell. Though all to ruin fell the world, and were dissolved and backward hurled unmade into the old abyss, yet were its making good, for this— the dawn, the dusk, the earth, the sea— that Lúthien on a time should be! {{references}} [[Category:Lays and tales within the legendarium]] [[Category:Songs]] [[fi:Eron laulu]]
